Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I was still wearing my white coat when I walked through the front door, my mind replaying the details of my last patient—a young woman with a runny nose and a cough, symptoms that could easily be dismissed as a common cold. But as a doctor, I knew I had to be thorough, to listen carefully, to not overlook anything that could be serious. My phone buzzed with a reminder to review her test results, but before I could sit down, I saw my younger brother slumped at the kitchen table, his backpack tossed aside, eyes red and puffy. He didn’t look up when I called his name. I knew something was wrong—he always tried to hide his feelings, but I could see the pain etched on his face. As his sibling, I wanted to drop everything, sit beside him, and let him talk about his day, to be the support he needed. But the weight of my responsibility as a doctor pressed on me; my patient was waiting for answers, and I couldn’t afford to make a mistake. Torn between comforting my brother and fulfilling my duty to my patient, I stood frozen, heart pounding, unsure which role to answer first.
